criteria: Ability to accurately name and differentiate between basic emotions (e.g., happiness, sadness, anger, fear).
Ability to recognize and name more complex emotions (e.g., frustration, disappointment, anxiety, relief).
Ability to understand and articulate the physical sensations and behavioral expressions associated with different emotions.
descriptions: Student cannot identify any emotions or provides inaccurate responses.
Student can identify 1-2 basic emotions with limited accuracy.
Student can identify 3-4 basic emotions with some inaccuracies or hesitation.
Student can accurately identify most basic emotions with minimal errors.
Student can accurately identify all basic emotions and provide simple examples of situations that might evoke them.
Student demonstrates mastery by accurately identifying basic emotions, providing examples, and explaining subtle differences between related emotions.
Student cannot identify any complex emotions or confuses them with basic emotions.
Student can identify 1 complex emotion with limited accuracy.
Student can identify 2-3 complex emotions with some inaccuracies or needs prompting.
Student can accurately identify most complex emotions but struggles to differentiate them.
Student accurately identifies complex emotions and can provide relevant examples.
Student demonstrates mastery by accurately identifying complex emotions, providing nuanced examples, and explaining their potential impact on behavior.
Student cannot connect emotions to physical sensations or behaviors.
Student attempts to connect emotions to physical sensations/behaviors but demonstrates significant inaccuracies.
Student can make some connections between emotions and physical sensations/behaviors with prompting.
Student can accurately describe some physical sensations or behaviors associated with common emotions.
Student can describe multiple physical sensations and behavioral expressions associated with a range of emotions.
Student demonstrates a thorough understanding of the connections between emotions, physical sensations, and behaviors, and can explain how these connections can vary between individuals.
